Q68_1:
(3/10) Heterogeneity Challenges - Hard to add integration and support for a new technology in IoT

For a device, communication or network protocol, external IoT platform or service, ...
Q68_2:
(3/10) Heterogeneity Challenges - Keeping up-to-date with latest releases in context of IoT is challenging

Devices, OS, protocols, or third party libraries may release updates too often or without prior notice.
Q68_3:
(3/10) Heterogeneity Challenges - Interpreting diverse technologies of IoT is challenging 

Challenge of Learning, understanding, and using each technology. Challenge of searching, choosing, and configuring a new technology to your current IoT system
Q70_1:
(4/10) Security Challenges - I'm not confident about the security of third-party components in my IoT system

Third-party components like network protocols, devices, libraries, operating systems,...
Q70_2:
(4/10) Security Challenges - Security mechanisms related to IoT devices are challenging due to device resource constraints

Challenges such as generating or storing tokens in devices,...
Q70_3:
(4/10) Security Challenges - Security is a complex problem in my IoT system

Existence of various attack surfaces, complex auth procedures, architectural complexity of the IoT system,...
Q67_1:
(5/10) Testing and Debugging Challenges - You need real devices for testing and debugging the IoT system

Device simulation and mocking IoT devices for the purpose of testing IoT is not practical yet
Q67_2:
(5/10) Testing and Debugging Challenges - Testing against diverse devices and protocols is a challenge

Hard to make sure your IoT system works well with all combinations of devices/protocols
Q67_3:
(5/10) Testing and Debugging Challenges - Logs and notification data from lower levels are not easily available

Have to manually investigate the failures and corruptions, not good failure reporting from lower level components
Q67_4:
(5/10) Testing and Debugging Challenges - Large-scale/edge-case scenarios are challenging while testing IoT

Hard to test and debug special states of the hardware, or environment... hard to test with lots of devices or test with large rates, or volume of data,...
Q67_5:
(5/10) Testing and Debugging Challenges - Reproducing the bug in IoT is a challenge

Hard to repeat the breaking scenario.
Q69_1:
(6/10) Other Challenges - Releasing patches and updates for my IoT system is challenging

Hard to release and deploy an update for my IoT system to fix/enhance a bug/feature without causing any breakage or too many effort
Q69_2:
(6/10) Other Challenges - Handling IoT data is challenging

Handling large scale or real-time data from IoT devices, keeping a back-up of data, not losing any telemetry data,...
Q69_3:
(6/10) Other Challenges - The IoT architecture is challenging to deal with

Challenge of designing the right architecture for the IoT system, avoiding complex or flawed architecture for the IoT system, or understanding and interpreting an existing architecture.
Q69_4:
(6/10) Other Challenges - Dealing with limitations of IoT devices is challenging

Restrictions of devices in supporting different technologies, constraint resources, known issues in some IoT devices,...
Q69_5:
(6/10) Other Challenges - Handling failures of IoT systems in a gentle way is challenging

Hard to handle failures in a way to not lose data and to keep the system available

Q71: The main challenge is the constrained resource on the hardware nodes. Some encryption algorithms or protocols might be too costly for them. Additionally, I think observability of the whole components as one "system" causes many issues. Even if some device provides log libraries and tools they should be manually aggregated or traced from each component separately to track an issue
Q77: Some bugs were caused by rare/unhandled states that the power source of the device can fail. For example: device should be able to write some persistent state to the memory or send some event to the hub/cloud. Or some execution rules on a device might be lost after the power loss so it will be up and running but not executing the function at the scheduled time.

Q77: I work on two projects: standard home/industrial IoT (devices with power supply) and low-power capacitor-backed wireless sensors. Although the first one serves as the bacbone for the second one, they're very different in light of firmware upgrading, communication protocols. So keep in mind questions about low-power/battery/ambient powered sensors/sensor networks would require special poll.

Q64: Others, please specify
Q64_4_TEXT: Services which don't interrect with devices directly are tested automatically, checking entire platform with devices requires manual testing
Q71: I think people who work closly to devices will have different opinion than people working on platform side. Internet connection is a big problem, devices need to opperate even when they can't access the platform. While number of events is higher than for systems which only interact with people, if there is a problem with IoT many customers won't notice, so the system feels more forgiving. Load is more stable, due to devices sending regularly messages, so system doesn't have high spikes in events like for websites which have high traffic only during specific hours.
Q77: Home alone mode for when device can't connect to the platform and makes it's own decisions is very helpful. Failed firmware update is automatically reverted by using two partitions with keeping existing firmware on one when installing new firmaware on second partition

Q71: The main challenge of an IoT developer is managing the large interaction-space of hardware and software. There are many separate configurations and responses from hardware, many of which can occur in parallel, that software needs to interact with correctly. Understanding all of the configurations and potential problems that can occur for each hardware chip is very time consuming.

Q71: IoT is a new space for a lot of developers who are not used to deeply embedded and/or remote systems. This causes a large number of devices to end up with security flaws, or the inability to deal with disconnection from a cloud or local servers. This is something embedded microcontroller engineers have dealt with for years, but we do not yet see the same solution robustness in IoT as in that field.

Q71: From my perspective, some key challenges are to build a secure system from end device to cloud service, designing and implementing software for very resource-constrained end devices, having robust software upgrades for remote networks, achieving long battery lifetimes, and achieving efficient communication in large networks. Some important challenges not seen in the survey are interoperability and dealing with regulations (e.g., ETSI.)
